active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the role of MASVS in addressing emerging mobile threats such as sideloading, emulator attacks, and data leakage. How does it contribute to verifiable secure app development in the SDLC, and what limitations might it have compared to general cybersecurity frameworks?
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

layer.name: Layer 1
layer.content: Define MASVS (OWASP Mobile Application Security Verification Standard); Core concepts (security requirements, verification, OWASP projects like MASTG and MASWE); Role in mobile app security and SDLC.

layer.name: Layer 2
layer.content: MASVS control groups with descriptions: MASVS-STORAGE (secure data storage), MASVS-CRYPTOGRAPHY (secure crypto implementation), MASVS-AUTHENTICATION (strong auth mechanisms), MASVS-NETWORK (secure communications), MASVS-PLATFORM (OS/platform interaction), MASVS-CODE (code quality, obfuscation, build integrity), MASVS-RESILIENCE (tamper detection, anti-reverse engineering). Security levels (L1: Standard, L2: Advanced, L3: Defense-in-Depth).

layer.name: Layer 3
layer.content: Steps to integrate MASVS into SDLC (requirements gathering, design reviews, implementation checks, verification with MASTG test cases); Applying controls to scenarios; Tools and techniques for verification per control group.

layer.name: Layer 4
layer.content: Combining MASVS with ASVS, ISO 27001, or OWASP Top 10; Case studies of compliant apps vs. breaches; Custom checklists; Mastery in emerging threats domain.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding
